articles.headline: ‘Retake Hong Kong’: A Movement, a Slogan and an Identity Crisis
articles.snippet: Hong Kong’s Beijing-backed government is struggling not only for control of the streets but over what the city means as a place and political entity.
articles.abstract: Hong Kong’s Beijing-backed government is struggling not only for control of the streets but over what the city means as a place and political entity.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — He has been locked up for more than a year in a secluded island jail, but the bespectacled 28-year-old inmate, Edward Leung, is the closest thing Hong Kong’s tumultuous and leaderless protest movement has to a guiding light.

articles.headline: Why an Heiress Spent Her Fortune Trying to Keep Immigrants Out
articles.snippet: Newly unearthed documents reveal how an environmental-minded socialite became an ardent nativist whose money helped sow the seeds of the Trump anti-immigration agenda.
articles.abstract: Newly unearthed documents reveal how an environmental-minded socialite became an ardent nativist whose money helped sow the seeds of the Trump anti-immigration agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: She was an heiress without a cause — an indifferent student, an unhappy young bride, a miscast socialite. Her most enduring passion was for birds.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: India Shut Down Kashmir’s Internet Access. Now, ‘We Cannot Do Anything.’
articles.snippet: Pharmacists can’t restock medicines; workers aren’t being paid. But the government still loves to block the internet for “peace and tranquillity.”
articles.abstract: Pharmacists can’t restock medicines; workers aren’t being paid. But the government still loves to block the internet for “peace and tranquillity.”
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Masroor Nazir, a pharmacist in Kashmir’s biggest city, Srinagar, has some advice for people in the region: Do not get sick, because he may not have any medicine left to help.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel, Karan Deep Singh and Sameer Yasir

articles.headline: Markets Are Shaken by New Signs of Global Economic Trouble
articles.snippet: Shares on Wall Street fell sharply after reports showed a slowdown in China and a contraction in Germany, partly reflecting the U.S. trade war’s impact.
articles.abstract: Shares on Wall Street fell sharply after reports showed a slowdown in China and a contraction in Germany, partly reflecting the U.S. trade war’s impact.
articles.lead_paragraph: The global economy is under increasing stress as growth cools and trade tensions take a mounting toll. On Wednesday, the tremors were felt worldwide.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz, Jack Ewing, Matt Phillips and Stephen Grocer

articles.headline: I Shared My Phone Number. I Learned I Shouldn’t Have.
articles.snippet: Our personal tech columnist asked security researchers what they could find out about him from just his cellphone number. Quite a lot, it turns out.
articles.abstract: Our personal tech columnist asked security researchers what they could find out about him from just his cellphone number. Quite a lot, it turns out.
articles.lead_paragraph: For most of our lives, we have been conditioned to share a piece of personal information without a moment’s hesitation: our phone number.

articles.headline: As Recession Concerns Mount, Dozens of Central Banks Are Cutting Rates
articles.snippet: More than 30 around the world have acted in the face of recession fears. Economists warn of a currency-tied competition.
articles.abstract: More than 30 around the world have acted in the face of recession fears. Economists warn of a currency-tied competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 30 central banks around the world have cut interest rates this year, as countries move to shore up their economies amid rising concerns over global growth, trade conflicts and the threat of a messy Brexit.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Karl Russell

articles.headline: ‘It’s Just a Nightmare.’ Despite Tariff Delay, Toy Makers Are Worried.
articles.snippet: Toymakers are already looking ahead to next year’s holiday season, and fretting about the crippling uncertainty that the president’s trade policy has created for them.
articles.abstract: Toymakers are already looking ahead to next year’s holiday season, and fretting about the crippling uncertainty that the president’s trade policy has created for them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Toymakers breathed a little easier this week when President Trump announced plans to delay tariffs on many goods from China — but their relief may not last long.

articles.headline: Many Democrats Love Elizabeth Warren. They Also Worry About Her.
articles.snippet: Even as she demonstrates why she is a leading presidential candidate, Ms. Warren is facing persistent questions and doubts about whether she would be able to defeat President Trump.
articles.abstract: Even as she demonstrates why she is a leading presidential candidate, Ms. Warren is facing persistent questions and doubts about whether she would be able to defeat President Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa — Senator Elizabeth Warren has built the most formidable campaign organization of any Democratic presidential candidate in the first nominating states, raised an impressive $25 million without holding high-dollar fund-raisers, and has risen steadily in Iowa and New Hampshire polls.

articles.headline: Israeli Decision on Omar and Tlaib Inflames Politics in Two Countries
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s call to bar the two congresswomen was an extraordinary step to influence an allied nation and punish his political opponents at home.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s call to bar the two congresswomen was an extraordinary step to influence an allied nation and punish his political opponents at home.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Under intense pressure from President Trump, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government on Thursday barred two members of the United States Congress from entering Israel for an official visit, reversing a previous decision to admit two of the president’s most outspoken critics.
articles.byline: By Isabel Kershner, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Peter Baker
